name: Michelle Bowman’s Apple Sauce
instructions: Peel apples, cut apples around core, cut apples into one inch chunks.
Combine apples, water and lemon juice into a pan.
Heat to boiling over medium heat.  Simmer uncovered stirring occasionally to break up apples, until tender – 5 to 10 min.
Mix nutmeg, cinnamon and sugar together.  Put in pan together.  Use low to medium heat.
Heat to a boil.  Cook for 1 minute until desired texture.
Cut off all but 2” of beet tops.
Wash beets and leave whole with root ends attached.
Heat 6 cups water, 1 tbsp. Vinegar (to preserve color) and 1 tsp. Salt.

Cover – heat to boil.  Reduce to medium boil until tender - 40 to 50 minutes; drain, run cold water over beets, slip off skins and remove root ends.  Slice.  Serve warm with butter, or cold with vinegar.
Thin asparagus spears work best in this elegant side dish.
10 green onions			   2red bell peppers cut into 20 strips
Snap off tough ends of asparagus.  Cover and cook in a small amount of boiling water 5 minutes or until crisp-tender.  Drain and rinse under cold water running water; drain well.
Trim white portion from green onions, and reserve for another use.  Place green onion tops in a bowl; adding boiling water to cover.  Drain immediately, and rinse under cold running water.
Gather asparagus into 10 bundles; add 2 bell pepper strips to each bundle.  Tie each bundle with a green onion strip.  Place bundles in 13x9 inch baking dish.
Combine chopped onion and next 9 ingredients (onion through pepper) in a bowl; stir well.  Pour over asparagus bundles.  Cover and chill 2 to 8 hours.
To serve, remove asparagus bundles from marinade, and discard marinade.  Arrange asparagus bundles on a serving platter.  Yield: 10 servings.
In a bowl, mix all cans of  corn, salt & pepper (to taste), parsley & thyme (to taste).
In another bowl, beat eggs, milk & flour thoroughly, then add to corn and mix again.
Pour into greased casserole, cover with breadcrumbs & butter, in slices.
1 Can whole kernel corn with juice
Mix together adding muffin mix last.
Bake in large 9x13 casserole dish 50-60 minutes at 350.
Layer in greased dish – first, onion, then soup, then cheese.
Add crackers and 1-2 tbsp. Butter on top
8 oz. plum tomatoes, skinned, seeded and finely chopped
1 tbsp. each chopped fresh basil, chives
Sea salt and freshly ground black pepper
In a large saucepan, saute the shallot with the olive oil for about 3 to 4 minute
Then add the mushrooms and continue to saute for another 5 minutes, stirring frequently until softened.
Stir in the rice and cook for another minute or two
Add the wine, stir and cook until absorbed.
Pour in a quarter of the chicken broth, bring to a boil and cook until absorbed, stirring frequently.
Gradually stir in the rest of the broth over a period of about 15 minutes, adding more as each previous amount is absorbed.  This helps to give you a creamy risotto.
When the rice is al dente, mix in the tomatoes and herbs.
Check the seasoning and stir in the cheeses.
Serve in warmed bowls topped with shaved aged parmesan.
2/3 cup plus 2 tbsp. shortening or 2/3 cup lard

Cut shortening into flour and salt until particles are size of small peas.  Sprinkle in water, 1 tablespoon at a time, tossing with fork until all flour is moistened and pastry almost cleans side of bowl (1 to 2 teaspoons water can be added if necessary).

Gather pastry into a ball; shape into flattened round on lightly floured cloth-covered board.  (For two-crust pie, divide pastry into halves and shape into 2 rounds).  Roll pastry 2 inches larger than inverted pie plate with floured stockinet-covered rolling pin.  Fold pastry into quarters; unfold and ease into plate, pressing firmly against bottom and side.
For baked pie shell: prick bottom and side thoroughly with fork.  Bake at 475 until light brown, 8 to 10 minutes; cool.

For two-crust pie: turn desired filling into pastry-lined pie plate.  Trim overhanging edge of pastry ½ inch from rim of plate.  Roll other round of pastry. Fold into quarters; cut slits so steam can escape.  Place over filling and unfold.  Trim overhanging edge of pastry 1 inch from rim of plate.  Fold and roll top edge under lower edge, pressing on rim to seal; flute cover edge with 2 to 3 inch strip of aluminum foil to prevent excessive browning; remove foil during last 15 minutes of baking.  Bake as directed in recipe.
Note:  if possible, hook fluted edge over edge of pie plate to prevent shrinking and help pastry retain its shape.

Whole wheat pastry: prepare filling before preparing pastry.  Substitute whole wheat flour for the all-purpose flour or substitute stone-ground whole wheat flour for half of the all-purpose flour.  Fold rolled pastry in half instead of into quarters.
1 baked 9-inch pie shell,  graham cracker or chocolate wafer crust
Combine the sugar and cornstarch in a heavy saucepan.
Whisk together the milk, cream and egg yolks.
Slowly add yolk mixture to sauce pan, constantly whisking
Cook over medium heat, stirring occasionally, for 5 minutes.
Then stir the mixture constantly until it comes to a boil, about 7 minutes more.
Remove the saucepan from heat and stir in the vanilla and butter.
Pour cooked filling into the baked pie shell and smooth top.
Finish with meringue or whipped cream topping.
Slice 1 Or 2 Bananas And Add To Cooked Filling Before Pouring Into Pie Shell.

Increase the sugar to 1 cup and add 3 tablespoon of powered chocolate to the cornstarch.  Melt 4 oz. Semisweet chocolate in 250 oven and stir into the cooked filling with the butter.  Pour into the baked pie shell.
Add 1 ½ cups flaked sweetened coconut to filling with butter.
Sprinkle toasted coconut over topping if you like.
Substitute ¾ cup well-packed dark-brown sugar for the granulated sugar.
1 ½ cups milk of 1-12 oz. can evaporated
Sift sugar, cornstarch, salt, cinnamon, ginger and nutmeg together.
Mix this with contents of one can one-pie pumpkin.
Add eggs, beaten, melted butter, molasses and milk.  Add a dash of lemon juice (if desired).
Line a 9-inch pie plate, pour in contents.
Preheat oven and bake at 450 for 15 minutes.
Then reduce temperature to 350 and continue to bake for 50 minutes.
Betty Crocker was almost as good as Mary Bowman
½ cup butter, part butter, melted
Mix as for piecrust, take ½ mixture and pack into pie pan.
Cook together until this mixture coats the spoon.
3 egg whites and 3 tbsp. granulated sugar.
Spread on top of custard.  Sprinkle remaining cracker crumb mixture over top of meringue.
Bake in 325 oven until meringue is brown.
Prep time: 25 Min	Bake Time: 10 min	Preheat Oven: 375°	Servings: 8
1 (9 inch) baked deep dish pie crust
Mix corn starch, 1 ½ cups sugar, water and egg yolks in saucepan over medium heat.
Stirring constantly, bring mixture to a boil (about 8 to 10 minutes), reduce heat and continue stirring for one minute until very thick.
Remove from heat; stir in lemon juice, lemon zest, and butter until smooth. Pour hot filling into pie crust.
Beat egg whites in mixer at high speed until soft peaks form; gradually add  ½  cup sugar and 2 teaspoons corn starch, beating until stiff peaks form (tips stand straight), about 3 minutes.
Top pie by spooning meringue over hot pie filling, making sure meringue touches edge of pie crust to seal. Use the back of a spoon to swirl meringue and draw up into peaks.
Bake: Place oven rack in bottom third of preheated oven. Bake 10 minutes, until peaks are lightly browned. Shut off oven and leave for 5 more minutes with door open
Cool at room temperature for 30 minutes. Chill for a minimum of 3 hours before serving.
Make pastry for 2 crust pie (see page42)
8 cups thinly sliced pared tart apple (about 7 medium McIntosh)
Heat oven to 425 degrees. Prepare pastry
Mix sugar, flour, nutmeg, cinnamon and salt
Turn into pastry lined pie plate
Cover with top crust and cut slits into it
Cover edge with aluminum foil; remove during the last 15 minutes of baking
Bake until crust is brown and juice beings to bubble through slits
Add 1 cup hot water – then add
Sift together – 3 cups flour (cake or regular) and 2 tsp. Baking powder
Add 1 cup hot water with 2 tsp. Baking soda dissolved.
NANA WOLFF’S POOR MAN’S FRUIT CAKE
Boil above ingredients 5 mins.  When cool add 2 tsp. Baking soda dissolved in one tbsp. lukewarm water.
Add 2 cups flour, ½ cup chopped nut meats, ½ jar candied cherries and ½ jar candied pineapple.  Mix fruit and nuts with flour.
Bake at least 1 ½ hours in greased and floured tube pan at 325. Double all ingredients for tube pan. Single recipe fits in 8x8 pans.
EASY APPLE COFFEE CAKE – NANA WOLFF
1 pkg. instant vanilla pudding (3 ¾ oz.)
½ cup salad oil (or ½ cup apple sauce)
Combine cake mix, pudding mix, eggs, sour cream and oil – beat 5 minutes
Pour ½ of batter into a greased 10” tube pan
Arrange ½ of apple slices on top and sprinkle with ½ mix of nuts, sugar and cinnamon
Add remaining apples and top with rest of sugar mixture
2 or 3 apples – thickly sliced into 1 tsp. cinnamon and 4 tsp. sugar
Mix all ingredients, except apples and cinnamon mixture, in a bowl.
Bake 350 – 60 to 70 minutes in a greased and floured tube pan.
Mom got this from Aunt Gracie Gaetani
1 cup blueberries + ¼ cup sugar, ¼ tsp. cinnamon
Sift flour, salt, baking powder – set aside
Cream shortening, sugar, and eggs, vanilla in a mixer or by hand.
Slowly add dry ingredients with milk and beat 3 minutes.
Sift together 2 ½ cups flour and ½ cup cocoa; set aside.
In large mixer bowl, combine 1 cup softened butter, 2 cups sugar and 1 cup brown sugar;
Add 6 egg yolks, one at a time, beating well after each addition.
Stir in 1 tsp. vanilla.  Combine 1 cup sour cream and ¼ tsp. baking soda.
Add to creamed mixture alternately with dry ingredients.
In separate bowl, Beat 6 egg whites until stiff; fold into batter.
Pour into well-greased and floured 10-inch tube pan.
Bake at 325 for 1 ½ hours, until toothpick inserted in center comes out clean.
Cool slightly; remove from pan; dust with confectioners’ sugar.
Tip:  to make design on cake, top with paper doily; dust on confectioners’ sugar.  Carefully remove doily
1 angel food cake (your favorite recipe or store bought)
2(20-ounce) cans crushed pineapple, drained, with juice set aside
Slice Angel Food Cake into 2 layers
Prepare Dream Whip according to directions
Combine 1 cup pineapple juice with 1 tablespoon cornstarch. Heat until thickened.
Layer cake with dream whip-pineapple mixture. Drizzle thickened juice over top of cake.
MARY BOWMAN - ONE-TWO-THREE-FOUR CAKE – BIRTHDAY CAKE
Heat oven to 350.  Grease and flour (2) 9-inch or (3) 8-inch round cake pans.
In large bowl of electric mixer, beat butter and sugar together until light and fluffy.
Beat in eggs one at a time.
Stir together sifted “cake flour” and baking powder.
Add alternately with vanilla and milk
Beating a low speed, until well combined.  Do not over beat.
Turn into prepared pans and bake until golden and centers sprig back when gently pressed
About 30 to 35 minutes for 9-inch pans or 20 to 25 minutes for 8-inch pans.
Cool 5 minutes in pans.  Remove from pans and cool.
Some versions of this basic yellow cake could probably be found in every grandmother’s recipe file In Pennsylvania Dutch families it was called Johnny’s birthday cake.
The ingredients – 1 cup butter, 2 cups sugar, 3 cups flour and 4 eggs – were easy to remember.
MARION DE VYLDER’S ITALIAN SPONGE CAKE
Separate eggs and beat whites first.  Set aside.
Add sugar to yolks and beat.
Add flour (sifted with baking powder and salt) to egg and sugar mixture alternating with hot water and extracts.
Fold in egg whites by hand.
For single recipe bake 325 for 30-40 minutes.
For large pan bake 1 ¼ hours.
For round pan, use double recipe.
1 heaping coffee mug of applesauce (homemade unsweetened)
Add applesauce and before stirring add spices on top of applesauce.
Add nuts & raisins to flour mixture.  This is done by hand.
Bake at 325/350 for 1 hour in a loaf pan lined with wax paper/Crisco.
Beat yolks, sugar and 3 tbsp. cold water till light.
Mix flour, cornstarch, baking powder and ¼ tsp. salt.
Beat into yolks; stir in lemon.
1 package Duncan Hines deluxe  white cake mix or Duncan Hines yellow cake mix
2 cans (20 to 23 oz.) Of pie filling*
*can use cherry, apple, blueberry, peach, strawberry, lemon, pineapple, pumpkin, or blackberry
Pour oil into a 13x9x2 inch pan, tilt pan to cover bottom.
Put cake mix, eggs and water into pan, stir with fork or spoon until blended (about 2 minutes).
Scrape sides and spread batter evenly in pan.
Spoon pie filling into batter; use a fork to fold into batter just enough to create a marbled effect.
Bake at 350 degrees for 35-45 minutes, until toothpick inserted near center comes out clean.
Cool cake.  May be sprinkled with powdered sugar.
Cut and serve directly from the pan.  Store cake loosely covered.
Drain can of mandarin oranges and chill oranges.
Reserve syrup – add water to syrup to make 1 cup.  Boil syrup mixture.  Stir in package of jello.  With an electric mixer, blend a half a cup of the hot mixture in 8 oz. package of cream cheese.
Pour into piecrust and chill to set.
Put the other half of the jello over the pie and decorate with oranges.
In a bowl sift the following 3 to 4 times
Beat until you can cut with a knife
Gradually combine mixtures until blended.  Pour into a 2 piece ungreased tube pan.
Increase to 350 and bake until brown.
Test with toothpick.  Remove from oven and invert over upturned funnel until cool.
Mix together.  Should not be runny.
4 cream cheese (4 non brand, or 2 Philly and 2 nonbrand)
Beat cream cheese and sugar till creamy.
24 graham crackers, finely crushed in plastic bag
Melt 6 tbsp. butter in small saucepan.
Measure 1 ½ cups of graham cracker crumbs into medium bowl.
Add ¼ cup sugar to the graham crackers.
Stir or blend together with hands.
Line with foil on the bottom of 9” Spring Form Pan
Place graham cracker crust in pan
Bake at 350 for 1 hour, and then watch every 10 minutes until done.
JOAN DWYER’S EASY ELEGANT STRAWBERRY CREAM CAKE
1 (9 inch) pie shell, baked and cooled (a frozen shell is fine)
1 (16 oz.) jar strawberry jam or preserves
1 thin slice sponge or chiffon cake
2 pt. fresh strawberries, washed, drained, hulled
Fill the pie shell with the whipped cream beaten with sugar & vanilla.
Cover the cream with the layer of cake, not more than ½” thick.
Stand the strawberries, crowded together on top of the layer (points standing up).
Heat the jam and while it is hot, pour it over the berries to glaze them.

Refrigerate several hours or overnight.  note:  was very difficult to cut, think maybe if put in freezer for a short time before serving, the whipped cream base would be a bit more firm.  Haven’t tried this yet myself, so first one to make it this way should call the second one!
Pour into two 9-inch layer pans, lined on bottoms with paper.
Pour in a circle over top of batter in pans about 1 inch from rims.
With spatula or knife, swirl chocolate in curlicues.
Cool and split each layer horizontally to make four layers.
Frost between layers with Mint Whipped Topping.
¼ cup crushed peppermint candy (8 peppermint candies) or use a few drops peppermint extract
Prepare topping mix with milk and vanilla as directed on envelope
9 slices white bread or 10 ¾ -ounce frozen pound cake (14 slices)
Cut crust from bread and cut each slice in half (or cut cake in ½ inch thick slices).
In bottom of a 1 ½ quart soufflé dish, place three pieces of bread (or 2 slices of cake).
Line sides of dish with about nine pieces of bread (or 8 slices of cake).
Brush remaining bread or cake with liqueur and set aside.
Beat cream with 2 tablespoons of sugar until it forms soft peaks.
In a large mixing bowl, mix strawberries with remaining sugar. Fold whipped cream into strawberries.
Spread half of the strawberry mixture into soufflé dish. Place three pieces of bread (two pieces of cake) on top.
Spread remaining strawberry mixture. Place remaining bread (or cake) on top. Cover and chill for several hours or overnight.
Carefully invert onto a serving plate. Garnish with additional berries if desired. To serve, cut into wedges. Top with additional whipping cream if desired. Serves 8.
Prep Time: 6 min	Bake Time: 12 Min
1 Container (8 oz.) frozen whipped topping, thawed
•	Mix strawberries and ½ cup sugar; set aside.
•	Heat oven to 425°F. Stir Bisquick mix, milk, 3 tbsp sugar and butter until soft dough forms.
•	Drop by 6 spoonful’s onto ungreased cookie sheet. Bake 10-12 min or until golden brown.
•	Split warm shortcakes; fill and top with strawberries and whipped topping. 6 shortcakes
MARY BOWMAN’S 7 MINUTE FROSTING – FLUFFY FROSTING
Combine in bowl and beat until thick.
MARY BOWMAN’S NO-COOK MARSHMALLOW FROSTING – FOR 1-2-3-4 CAKE
¾ cup karo crystal-clear or all-purpose syrup
Beat egg whites and salt with electric or rotary beater until soft peaks form.
Add sugar, about 1 tbsp. at a time, beating until smooth and glossy.
Continue beating and adding karo syrup, a little at a time, beating after each addition, until frosting peaks.
Fold in vanilla.  Makes enough to frost 2 (9-inch) layers
3 squares (3 ounces) Hershey’s premium unsweetened chocolate
In top of double boiler over hot, not boiling water, melt chocolate
Add marshmallows; stir frequently until melted
Pour mixture into small mixer bowl; beat in butter and milk until smooth
Add sugar and vanilla; beat to desired consistency. About 2 ½ cups frosting
2 ½ cups flour – ½ tsp. baking powder – sift together
MARY BOWMAN’S CHRISTMAS COOKIES PECAN – CHERRY SLICES
2 ¼ cups flour with a dash of salt
Gradually add sugar, beat until light.
With floured hands, roll into 3 logs, wrap in wax paper
Add flour and pecans then roll into balls
Roll in more powdered sugar while warm
Cream butter with sugar and nuts.
Sift flour with salt and add slowly mixing well.
Wrap in wax paper and refrigerate overnight.
Take dough and roll between 2 sheets of waxed paper.
Place on greased and lightly floured cookie sheet.
With a spoon put meringue on cookie and spread out.
Bake at 350 for 12-15 minutes.  (Put sprinkles on before baking).
Meringue – fold ½ cup sugar into stiffly beaten egg whites.
Work in shortening, eggs and anise.
Knead on a floured board and roll dough to ¼ inch.
¾ cup sugar				 Add sugar to butter, then add eggs.
Add the following to the mixture above
Shape dough into balls and place in ungreased cookie sheet.
Frost and decorate while cookies are still warm.
Bake at 350, about 15 minutes (will not get brown)
While still warm, roll in confectioners’ sugar
Cream shortening and add sugar gradually, while beating constantly.
Add egg, well beaten, orange juice and orange rind.
Sift flour, salt and baking soda and add with nuts to sugar mixture.
Place in waxed paper over night.
Slice and roll them and cut out cookies.
Mix shortening, sugar, egg and molasses.
Sift and stir in dry ingredients.
Form into balls about 1 inch in diameter, then roll lightly in granulated sugar.
Blend together crisco, sugar, salt, vanilla and egg.
Drop by teaspoon onto a greased cookie sheet.
Make a small dent in center of each cookie and fill with jam or jelly.
Bake in 375 degree oven for 10 to 12 minutes.
*orange, lemon or almond extract may also be used.
Combine flour and yeast, cut in butter
Mix egg yolks with sour cream and mix into flour mixture (dough will be stiff)
Form into a ball and refrigerate overnight
Mix together nuts, sugar, cinnamon and cocoa
Roll each part in the sugar mixture
Roll the dough thin and cut into 8 pie wedges
Dot each wedge at wide end with a small amount of raspberry or strawberry jelly or jam
Roll each wedge from wide end to tip to form a crescent
Bake on a greased cookie sheet at 350 degrees for 20-25 minutes
Mix 2 ¼ cups flour with ½ tsp. Salt. Set aside
Beat in a medium bowl.  1 cup butter (at room temperature) and 1 cup sugar until light and fluffy.
Gradually beat in flour mixture until just blended.
Divide in half.  Wrap in waxed paper and chill ½ hour.
Roll half dough on slightly floured surface until ¼ inch thick.
Cut 1 ½” stars from centers, continuing until you have a matching number of tops and bottoms.
Bake at 350 degrees for 8-10 minutes, until lightly golden.
Assemble tops and bottoms when cool (Ellen does it the next day) with “glue” of warmed strawberry jam.
Ellen says she makes millions and millions of these every Christmas!
Go to the pantry and open the drawer (you know which one)
Take out the crackers and bring them to nana.
Open the refrigerator and take out the jelly – bring it to nana.

Have nana spread the jelly on the saltines for you – they taste better that way (cuz she spreads then with love as well as jelly).  If you’re good, she might make you a cup of coffee with lots of milk to go with them.  Then sit at the counter and chat with the best grandmother that ever lived!
IT DOESN’T GET ANY BETTER THAN THAT!
MUST BE LIKE ADDIE’S FROM SWEDEN
To one half basic dough, Mix in 1 teaspoon grated orange peel.
Shape dough by rounded teaspoonfuls into pencil-like strips about 5 inches long.
Form each strip into a circle, overlapping ½ inch at each end.
Brush tops lightly with slightly beaten egg white; sprinkle with granulated sugar.
Press bits of red candied cherries on center of overlap for holly berries; add little leaves of green candied cherries or citron.
Bake on ungreased baking sheet for 8 to 10 minutes or until set, but not brown.  Immediately remove from baking sheet.
Sift flour, sugar and salt together; work in butter and vanilla.
Add 2 cups of nuts, mix well.  Shape into 1 inch balls.
Roll half of the balls in remaining nuts.
Place onto a greased cookie sheet.
Bake at 350 degrees for about 25 minutes.
Roll the plain cookies in fine granulated sugar while warm.
Mix together and roll into balls:
Melt 12 oz. Pkg. of chocolate chips with 2 tbsp. shortening.
Dip balls into chocolate (~3/4 way) and place on wax paper to harden.
Sift flour, baking soda and salt together.
Beat in peanut butter, butter, brown sugar and ½ cup sugar until creamy.
Add in everything else and mix well.
Shape dough into 1” balls and roll balls in the remaining sugar to coat.
Bake 10 minutes at 350 and then place in kiss and cook for 2 more minutes.
3 cups Quaker® Oats (quick or old fashioned, uncooked)
In large bowl, beat butter and sugars until creamy.
Add egg and vanilla; beat well.
Add combined flour, baking soda, cinnamon, salt and nutmeg; mix well.
Drop dough by rounded tablespoonful onto ungreased cookie sheets.
Bake 8 to 9 minutes for a chewy cookie or 10 to 11 minutes for a crisp cookie.
Cool 1 minute on cookie sheets; remove to wire rack.
•	ANNIE WOLFF REGAN’S SWEDISH SPRITZ COOKIES
Mix together butter, sugar, egg & flavoring
Work flour in with your hands.
Use cookie press to form cookies.
If dough won’t hold shape, refrigerate for a short time but don’t make dough too cold.
SALLY VELCOFSKY - PUMPKIN COOKIES WITH BROWN-BUTTER ICING
11 ounces (2 ¾ sticks) unsalted butter, softened
1 ½ cups canned solid-pack pumpkin (14 ounces)
1 cup plus 1 tbsp. Evaporated milk, plus more if needed
Preheat oven to 375. Line baking sheet with parchment paper; set aside.
Fit a pastry bag with a large coupler and ½-inch plain round tip; set aside.
Whisk together four, baking powder, and baking soda, salt, cinnamon, ginger, and nutmeg in a medium bowl; set aside.
Cream 12 tbsp (1 ½ sticks) butter and the brown sugar on medium speed in the bowl of an electric mixer until pale, about 2 minutes.
Mix in eggs, scraping down sides of bowl as needed. On low speed, add pumpkin, ¾ cup milk, and 1 tsp. Vanilla; mix until combined, about 2 minutes.

Add flour mixture; mix scraping down sides and bottom of bowl as needed, until well combined. Transfer 1 ½ cups batter to pastry bag. Holding tip close to parchment paper, pipe 1 ½-inch rounds 1 inch apart.
Repeat with remaining batter. Bake until tops are springy to the touch, about 12 minutes. Let cool on sheets 5 minutes; transfer to wire racks to cool completely.
Meanwhile, put confectioner’s sugar in a large bowl; set aside. Melt remaining butter in a small saucepan over medium heat.
Cook until golden brown, about 3 minutes. Immediately pour butter over confectioner’s sugar, scraping any brown bits from sides and bottom of pan.
Add remaining 5 tbsp milk and remaining 2 tsp. Vanilla; stir until smooth. Spread about 1 tsp. icing on each cookie (if icing becomes stiff stir in a little more evaporated milk until spreadable).
Cookies can be stored in an airtight container up to 3 days. Makes about 6 dozen.
1 cup (6 oz.) Package semi-sweet chocolate bits
Blend sugar, butter and milk in saucepan.
Bring just to a boil, stirring constantly.
Blend flour, baking powder, salt and baking soda.
Stir into chocolate bits and nuts.
Spread in greased and floured 13x9x2 inch pan.
Cool; cut into 2 inch by 1 inch bars.
Beat eggs and add to cream mixture.
Bake at 350 for 25-30 minutes or until golden.
Cool slightly and cut into small squares.
Mix butter, sugar & eggs, beat well, stir in apples, and add nuts.
Sift dry ingredients and blend with apple mixture.
Melt butter in glass 9 x 13 pan
Dump in crumbs mix with melted butter,
Add milk, 2 layers of chips, coconut
Bake 25-35 minutes till edges are brown cool completely before cutting
2/3 to ¾ cup brown sugar packed
Mix rest ingredients thoroughly sprinkle on top.
8 cups peeled, cored ¼” sliced, tart cooking apples (about 8-10 medium)
For crust, add enough milk to egg yolk to measure 2/3 cup; set aside.
In medium bowl, combine flour and salt.
With fork, stir in milk mixture until dough forms a ball; divide into halves.
Roll out ½ of the dough, on lightly floured surface, into a 15x10 ½” rectangle.  Place on bottom of ungreased 15x10x1” jellyroll pan.
before filling, sprinkle cereal over top
In small bowl, combine 1 cup granulated sugar, 1 ½ tsp. Cinnamon and nutmeg.
Roll remaining ½ of dough into a 15 ½” x 10 ½” rectangle, place over apples.
In small bowl, with fork beat egg white until foamy; brush over top crust.
In another small bowl, stir together 2 tbsp. Granulated sugar and ½ tsp. Cinnamon; sprinkle over crust.
Bake 45 to 60 minutes, or until lightly brown.
For glaze, in small bowl, stir together all glaze ingredients.
Filling – dissolve cornstarch, sugar, egg in a pan with a can of crushed pineapple
Blend shortening into flour with pastry cutter
Roll half of dough – put onto cookie sheet 9x13
Put in filing and then add top crust.
Frost with mixture confectionery sugar, hot water & little vanilla.
2 ½ cups gold medal flour (gold medal self-rising flour can be used in this recipe)
Heat oven to 350 degrees.  Grease oblong pan, 13x9x2 inches.
To one half basic dough, mix in ½ cup quick-cooking oats and ½ cup brown sugar (packed).  (Dough will be crumbly).
Par firmly and evenly into prepared pan.
Bake about 15 minutes or until no imprint remains when lightly touched with finger.
Remove from oven; immediately sprinkle ½ cup semi-sweet chocolate pieces evenly over crust.  Place baking sheet over pan so contained heat will soften chocolate pieces.
Spread softened chocolate evenly over crust; sprinkle with ½ cup chopped nuts.  While warm, cut into 1 ½ inch diamond shapes.  Makes about 2 ½ dozen.
Use glass to cut into round shaped pastry
Place in the bottom of muffin pan
Fill with strawberry preserves or apricot any kind of preserves that you like.
Use box or homemade* white cake mix added on top of preserves
*Eddie prefers homemade. Usually made from scraps when making pies.
¾ cup Quaker or Aunt Jamima enriched corn meal
Stir in milk, oil and egg, mixing just until dry ingredients are moistened.
Bake 20 to 25 minutes or until light golden brown and wooden pick inserted near center comes out clean.  Serve warm.  9 servings.
Or better yet mix up a box of Jiffy Corn Muffin Mix
1 – 15 oz. Box raisin bran or bran flakes with 1 cup raisins
Combine first 5 ingredients in a large bowl and blend well.
Combine buttermilk, eggs and oil and stir into dry ingredients just until blended.
When ready to use, preheat oven to 400 (we use 350).
Fill cupcake papers ¾ full and bake 20 minutes or until toothpick comes out clean.  Keeps 6 weeks in refrigerator. Makes 4 or 5 dozen.
Mix sugar, egg, milk, banana and bisquick.
Beat vigorously for 30 seconds.  Stir in walnuts.
Bake 350 – 45 to 50 minutes until toothpick stuck into center comes out clean.
Crack in top is typical.  Cool before slicing
The boys used to sit on the stairs at the old house and sing this when Irene brought Mom some bread....
Irene’s banana bread tastes like crap!
Kiki thinks we should add “I sat down and ate a little bit and I really do think it tastes like Crap!
Bake in greased & floured loaf pan 45-60 minutes at 325.
Grease a deep pan, 2 ½ quart casserole with unsalted shortening.
In a large bowl sift together flour, sugar, baking powder and salt.
Stir caraway seeds into dry ingredients.
Add butter and cut it in with a pastry blender or 2 knives until mixture is the consistency of coarse corn meal.
Place buttermilk, egg and baking soda in a small bowl and beat together with a rotary beater until blended.
Add egg mixture to dry ingredients, stirring until dry ingredients are blended in.
Turn out dough onto a floured board and knead lightly about 3 minutes, until dough is smooth.
Shape dough into a ball and place in prepared casserole.
With a sharp knife, cut an “x” about ½ inch deep into the top of the dough.
Beat together egg yolk and water with a rotary beater and brush mixture over top of the dough.
Bake 60 to 65 minutes, or until a cake tester inserted in center of the bread comes out clean.
Remove bread from oven and cool completely.
*to make sour milk: stir 1 1/3 tbsp. Lemon juice or white vinegar into 1 1/3 cups sweet milk and let stand 5 minutes before using.
With a wooden spoon, cream the butter and sugar.
Add 1 cup of flour and mix well.  Add second cup. Mix well, and finally the last cup.  You may have to work in the final cup with your hands.
Pat the dough firmly into an 8x8 inch cake pan and bake at 325 for 50 minutes.
Before you bake, make a fancy design on the outer edges with the tines of a fork.
1 cup drained whole red maraschino cherries
Grease and line a loaf pan with waxed paper
In a sifter, place flour, sugar, baking powder and salt
In a large bowl, place nuts, dates and cherries
Sift flour mixture over the nuts and fruit
Add the extract to the eggs then add it to the nut mixture, stirring well
1 pkg. (8 oz.) Pitted dates, cut up
Blend all ingredients in large mixer bowl ½ minute, scraping bowl frequently.
Pour batter into greased & floured loaf pan (9x5x3).
Bake about 1 hour and 10 minutes or until toothpick inserted in center comes out clean.
Grease bottoms of 2 loaf pans.  Mix oil and sugar, add eggs, zucchini and water.
Blend in flour, baking soda, salt, baking powder, cinnamon & cloves.
½ cup warm water (110-115 degrees approx.)
¼ tsp. baking soda dissolved in 1 tbsp warm water
Combine yeast, sugar, and warm water in a large bowl; stir until the yeast and sugar are dissolved, and let the mixture sit until it starts to foam.
Add the flour, mixed with the salt, and the warm milk in alternate portions while stirring vigorously with a wooden spoon.

Holding the bowl tightly, beat the dough very hard until it shows some elasticity and looks almost ready to leave the bowl (unlike kneaded dough, it will remain loose and sticky). When it has a gummy quality, cover and let rise in a warm place for about an hour – hour and a half, until doubled in bulk.
Stir down with a wooden spoon, add the dissolved soda, and beat vigorously again for about 1 minute, being careful to distribute the soda thoroughly, or else the bread will be streaked.
Butter a 9x5 inch pan and fill with the dough, using a rubber spatula to scrape it from the bowl. Cover lightly with a plastic wrap.
Let it rise again in a warm place for about 1-1 ¼ hours.
Bake the bread in a preheated 375 degree oven until it’s golden on top and slightly shrinks from the sides of the pan.
Cool in pans for about 5 minutes, and then turn onto a rack.
Beat egg white in medium bowl on high until foamy.
Gradually add 3 tbsp. sugar beating until soft peaks form.
Mix remaining 3 tbsp. Sugar. Combine sugar, tapioca (shake box before using), milk and egg yolk in saucepan.
Cook and stir constantly over medium heat until mixture comes to a full boil.  (Pudding thickens as it cools).
Remove from heat; quickly fold in egg white mixture until well blended.
Stir in vanilla – cool 20 minutes – serves 6.
ORIGINAL NESTLE TOLL HOUSE CHOCOLATE CHIP COOKIES
¾ cup firmly packed brown sugar
2 cups (half of 24 oz. Pkg.) Nestle toll house semi-sweet chocolate chips
In small bowl, combine flour, baking soda and salt; set aside.
In large mixer bowl, beat butter, sugar, brown sugar and vanilla extract until creamy.  Beat in eggs.
Drop by rounded measuring tablespoonfuls onto ungreased cookie sheets.
Bake 9-11 minutes.  Makes about 5 dozen 2 ¼’” cookies.
9 slices firm white bread or one 10 ¾ ounce frozen pound cake – 14 slices
Cut crusts from bread and cut each slice in half crosswise (or cut cake into ½ inch thick slices).
In the bottom of a 11/2 quart soufflé dish or charlotte mold, place 3 pieces of bread (2 slices cake) on top and spread with remaining strawberry mixture.
Place 3 pieces of bread (2 slices cake) on top.
Cover; chill several hours over night.
Carefully invert onto a serving plate.
Garnish with additional berries, if desired.
To serve, cut into wedges.  Top with additional whipped cream, if desired.
Combine milk, rice, sugar, raisins and salt in saucepan.
Bring to a boil, stirring constantly.
Reduce heat and simmer, uncovered for 5 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Combine eggs, vanilla and nutmeg in 1-quart casserole.
Slowly stir in hot rice mixture, blending well.
Sprinkle with additional nutmeg, if desired.
Place casserole in pan of warm water.
Bake at 375 for 20-25 minutes, or until set.
Cool at least 1 hour.  Serve warm or chilled.  Makes 6 to 8 servings.
NOTE: EDDIE DOESN’T LIKE RAISINS IN HIS PUDDING
½ bottle white wine (drink the other ½ before the guests arrive)
Juice from 1 can (8 oz.) Crushed pineapple
Prepare jello with 2 cups boiling water and pineapple juice.  Cool until it begins to thicken.
½ cup heavy cream whipped (1 cup cool whip)
Combine soft cream cheese, cream, mustard, pineapple and carrot.
When Jell-O begins to thicken, add to cheese mixture and pour into greased (pam) mold – refrigerate until jelled.
½ cup sugar and ¼ cup sugar
Grease 1 qt. Casserole or 6-7 custard cups.
Beat egg whites and salt at high speed until soft peaks form – gradually add ½ cup sugar until sugar dissolves and stiff peaks form.

At medium speed, beat egg yolks with ¼ cup sugar, add milk and rest of ingredients and beat until well mixed.  With rubber spatula or wisk gently fold in egg yolks just until mixed.  Pour into casserole.

Set casserole or custard cups in 13”x9” baking pan – fill baking pan halfway with boiling water.  Bake 55-65 minutes until top is golden and firm.  (Pudding separates into cake layer on top, sauce underneath).  Serve as is or top with whipped cream.  Bake custard cups in pan with boiling water for 40-45 minutes.
ANNE MARGARET REGAN CALLAN’S CHERRY JELLO FRUIT SALAD
1 sm. can crushed pineapple		½ to 1 cup nuts
1 sm. jar maraschino cherries		2 sm. pkgs. cream cheese
1 sm. pkg. cherry jello			16 oz coca cola
Drain fruit juices into 2 cup measuring cup.
Add enough coca cola to make 2 cups.
Pour into sauce pan and heat until foaming.
Stir in jello and refrigerate until it begins to thicken.
Cube cream cheese and add with fruit and nuts to thickened Jell-O.
Let set in fridge for 12 hours before serving.

At Thanksgiving, substitute cranberry Jell-O, cranberries and cranberry juice if desired.  Cut up the cranberries and put them in hot cranberry juice to soften.  Then use the cranberry juice like the cherry juice in the recipe.
Grind ham adding pickles everyone once and a while
Continue Grinding  pickles with ham alternating
Only use bumble bee white albacore in water
Drain well, wash with water drain well again
With fork - break up into very small pieces
Add 1 to 2 tbsp of Hellman’s mayo
Add small pieces of celery or onion, if you like

COLD WATER METHOD:  Place eggs in saucepan; add enough cold water to come at least 1 inch above eggs.  Heat rapidly to boiling; remove from heat.  Cover and let stand until desired doneness, 1 to 3 minutes.  Immediately cool eggs in cold water for several seconds to prevent further cooking.  Cut eggs in halves; scoop eggs from shells.

COLD WATER METHOD:  Place eggs in saucepan; add enough cold water to come at least 1 inch above eggs.  Heat rapidly to boiling; remove from heat.  Cover and let stand 13 minutes.  Immediately cool eggs in cold water to prevent from further cooking.  Tap egg to crackle shell.  Roll egg between hands to loosen shell, then peel.  Hold egg under running cold water to help ease off shell.
Heat water (1 ½ to 2 inches) to boiling; reduce to simmering.  Break each egg into custard cup or saucer; holding cup or saucer close to water’s surface.  Slip 1 egg at a time into water.
Cook until desired doneness, 3 to 5 minutes.  Remove eggs from water with slotted spoon.

Heat margarine, butter or bacon fat in heavy skillet to 1/8-inch depth just until hot enough to sizzle a drop of water.  Break each egg into custard cup or saucer; carefully slip 1 egg at a time into skillet.  Immediately reduce heat to low.
Cook, spooning margarine onto eggs, until whites are set and a film forms over yolks (sunny-side up).  Or gently turn eggs over when whites are set and cook until desired doneness.
For each serving, stir 2 eggs, 2 tablespoons milk or cream, ¼ teaspoon salt and dash of pepper with fork.  Stir thoroughly for a uniform yellow, or slightly for streaks of white and yellow.
Heat 1 ½ teaspoons margarine or butter in skillet over medium heat just until hot enough to sizzle a drop of water.  Pour egg mixture into skillet.

As mixture begins to set at bottom and side, gently lift cooked portions with spatula so that thin, uncooked portion can flow to bottom.  Avoid constant stirring.  Cook until eggs are thickened throughout but still moist, 3 to 5 minutes.

For each serving, stir in 2 tablespoons of one or more of the following:  shredded cheddar, Monterey jack or Swiss cheese; chopped mushrooms; snipped chives; snipped parsley; crisply cooked and crumbled bacon*; finely shredded dried beef*; chopped fully cooked smoked ham.*
